description: Walking tour introducing nine smaller local parks and public gardens, and revealing their history. Led by Clare Graham, Chair of the Society's Open Spaces Committee and author of 'Discovering Battersea's Open Spaces: a walking guide'.

factsheet.heading: Latchmere Recreation Ground
paragraphs: The centrepiece of the Latchmere Estate, pioneering social housing built by Battersea Borough Council using direct labour in 1902-3. On the site of Latchmere Common (enclosed 1838). Nearby were public baths of 1889 (now replaced by Latchmere Leisure Centre) and a coroner's court (1899-1902, by Borough Surveyor J T Pilditch; now a nursery). Latchmere Rec became famous as the site of the Brown Dog Riots of 1907, provoked by its anti-vivisectionist monument (1906; removed 1910, replaced 1985 by a new Brown Dog Memorial in Battersea Park).

factsheet.heading: Falcon Park
paragraphs: Created by London County Council, opened 1966. Enclosed within railway lines; known informally as Banana Park, for its shape. One of a number of new parks created within local post-Second World War slum clearance programmes. The site was formerly Latchmere Grove, Victorian terraced housing still occupied in 1953 as a faded Coronation mural on its South wall shows.

factsheet.heading: Shillington Park
paragraphs: Adjoins Falcon Park; another post-WW2 park, opened c. 1977 by Wandsworth Council and serving as a 'back garden' for its neighbouring Falcon Estate. Site previously occupied by Victorian terraces (Shillington Street, Stainforth Road), then prefab housing and a travellers' site.  At its South end can be seen Christchurch Primary School's 'secret garden,' an award-winning community project.

factsheet.heading: Falcon Glade
paragraphs: Pocket park created by Wandsworth Council in 2014 from spare ground bordering the Falcon Estate. A small green refuge beside busy Falcon Road, opposite the Grant Road entrance to Clapham Junction station.

factsheet.heading: York Gardens
paragraphs: Popular community park, opened 1972 by Wandsworth Council; architects Howes, Jackman & Partners. Houses York Gardens Library and Community Centre (1982, Wandsworth Council) and the Falconbrook Pumping Station (1961-3, London County Council; being rebuilt within Thames Water's super sewer project). The park is due to be resited and relandscaped within the ongoing regeneration of the York Road and Winstanley Estates.

factsheet.heading: Harroway Gardens
paragraphs: Small hummocky green space and playground created in the late 1970s, to replace war-damaged Victorian terraced housing. Behind rises Barrett's riverside Lombard Wharf, 2016, architects Patel Taylor.

factsheet.heading: Vicarage Gardens
paragraphs: Overlooking the Thames, and the Thames Path. Created on an area of reclaimed foreshore and laid out as a public recreation ground by Battersea's Borough Surveyor J T Pilditch in 1896, with financial support from the Metropolitan Public Gardens Association.

factsheet.heading: Fred Wells Gardens
paragraphs: Another post-WW2 neighbourhood park beside railway lines with tennis court, playgrounds and attractive landscaping. Created in the early 1980s by Wandsworth Council, and named after a popular local Labour councillor (d.1982). Here previously was Battersea Greyhound Stadium and athletic track, and cleared  Victorian and prefab housing.

factsheet.heading: Christchurch Gardens
paragraphs: A corner site originally intended as a graveyard for neighbouring Christ Church (1847-9, rebuilt 1957-9). Never used for burials, it was converted by the Metropolitan Public Gardens Association into one of its 'outdoor drawing-rooms for the poor' in 1885; taken over by the local authority in 1889. Redesigned after the Second World War as a formal setting for a Grade II memorial commemorating Battersea's 500+ civilian war dead (1951, designed by the Borough Engineer and Surveyor).

travel_info: Nearest train: Queenstown Road (Battersea), Battersea Park, Clapham Junction

name: Battersea's Hidden Parks
